...But... chemistry.
Assuming the fracking fluid is less dense than the surrounding bedrock (and most liquids are less dense than solids) then it will naturally rise upwards. It would be safely contained if the caprock had not been so thoroughly shattered. But now the caprock has several holes, filled by permeable sands -- the permeability of sand being part of the reason it works for retrieving oils and gases in fracking in the first place. It might not escape within the lifetime of the billionaires doing the fracking. But it will escape eventually. And because the fluid contains anti-bacterial substances, it cannot be naturally percolated by bacterial digestion as it rises, which means it cannot be fully purified via natural means either, not just by treatment plants. If a well needs to be fracked to be able to produce oil or gas, it is highly likely that the formation targeted is not very porous to begin with. The fractures made follow the grain of the rock horizontally out from the wellbore and don't travel up and down through other formations. If drinking water becomes contaminated it is likely from a hole that has formed in the production and intermediate casing closer to the surface or from bad cement  behind the casing that allows gas to migrate from below, nothing to do with fracking. I am a Geologist and Geophyisicist.  This video is so wrong on so many points.   "The fracking revolution" is a total misnomer.  It is a "Shale Revolution".  We have been fracking for 70 years.  We have been horizontal Drilling for over 40 years.  We just started applying these to tight Shale....that is what is new.  The claim that using gas from Fracked wells for energy produces the same amount of  CO2 as from other fossil fuels is a complete fabrication.  For the same caloric output, Gas produces only 25-50% of the CO2 than Coal.  If the CO2 release from Fracking alone brought the total CO2 output from Fracked Energy usage to 100%, it would mean that the act of Fracking produces 2-3 times the CO2 than from burning the gas it produces, meaning you put in ~2-3 times as much energy as you get out...we would actually have less energy than we had before we Fracked, and every company that did it would have gone bankrupt years ago.  That is complete and utter nonsense.  The use of Fracking in tight shales to produce natural gas has lowered the US CO2 output far more than all our new renewable sources like Wind, Solar, Biofuels, etc. combined.  That is indisputable.  Also, that 3% loss of methane is dubious at best, and would be no different than conventional gas production.  Any gas loss has nothing to do with Fracking.  It was just a claim in the video that was completely unsubstantiated.  The Video also does not accurately represent what Fracking Fluid is.  In fact, Fracking Fluid is 99.5% sand and water.  Most of the remaining 0.5% is Guar.  It is a very common and safe thickening agent.  It makes the the fluid more viscous, which helps it fracture the rock and push sand into the cracks, when under pressure.  If Guar sounds familiar, look at a container of ice cream.  Chances are, it contains Guar Gum...the exact same thing that is in Fracking Fluid.  The rest of the fluid (usually less than 0.1%) is any of a number of chemicals that are typically less toxic than many components of the Geofluids that are naturally already down there, and they are in very small quantities.  Fracking fluid is also often recovered after use and recycled for use in other wells.  The video states that the fluid is highly toxic which is totally not true...Governor Hickenlooper from Colorado (Democrat) drank a glass of it at a Press Conference to prove this point a few years ago.  Hickenlooper is also a Geologist, so he knows the truth.  The Video also implies that the Fracking fluid has contaminated freshwater sources through fractures in the Earth created by Fracking.  This is a complete lie.  This has never happened.  Fracking cracks the rock only within ~50ft of the horizontal borehole.  We know this, due to geophysical monitoring of the process.  These horizontal bores are typically at depths of 5,000-10,000ft below the surface (1-2 miles below the surface).  Water wells and water sources are typically at depths of less than 1000ft. That means the 50-ft fractures occur almost 1-2 miles below these fresh water sources.  It is virtually impossible for Fracking (which can only produce ~50ft fractures) to create a 4000-9000ft fracture.  You would need nuclear weapons to do something like that.  Any contamination has happened from accidental spills at the surface.  It is very rare, and again it is not that toxic, if at all.  Fertilizer tankers and trucks spill all the time and are far more toxic than most Fracking fluid.  Yet I don't see anyone freaking out about them.  There is a risk with everything we do.  The idea is to mitigate risk as much as possible until the benefits far outweigh the risks.  This is why people don't freak out over Fertilizer trucks or car accidents, or riding bikes without helmets.  But Fracking is far more safe and far more regulated and scrutinized than any of the risks we live with happily.  It is because of politics, votes, virtue signaling, misdirected activism, etc.  There are so many other things wrong with this video, I could go on for hours, but I think you get the point.  This is an Activist video with little to no truth to any of their claims.

Drilling and fracturing are two separate and unrelated procedures. If you tried to drill a well by using fracturing... well that isn't even possible... you need an existing conduit to channel hydraulic fracturing fluids- primarily made of jelly created from guar gum (made from beans) that stick to the rock and reduce its permeability, so then the "hydraulic" part comes in when you pump water down there... the jelly makes the rock less permeable so the water won't soak into it, instead it creates pressure which pulverizes the rock... aka "fracturing. Then the hydrocarbons are now freed from the rock but are require some help to loosen them up, which is where "pickling" comes in. 4. The only real possible case in which groundwater might get contaminated is when well is not properly sealed due to major technological processes violations, or those chemicals are simply leaked or dumped on the surface, which has nothing to do with fracking itself.

Some things they didn't mention that they should have:

The actual fracturing occurs between 10 and 20x as deep as the deepest aquifers we use for drinking water.
The rock layers between these aquifers and fracturing 'sites' are the least-permeable in the earth's upper crust and are nearly impossible for liquid to penetrate regardless of the chemicals used.
All recorded cases of ground water contamination have been due to the failure of the well-head shaft (the top 100-500 feet of the well wall) due to poor project management and negligence.
Proper safety precautions and standards of construction/engineering (regulations) would result in the near-full mitigation of any risk of ground water contamination (within the next couple centuries).
The only real concern regarding ground water (assuming responsible well construction and engineering) will surface (pun intended) hundreds of years from now when significant costs of maintenance and containment arise regardless of previous precautions and standards during well construction.
The largest unmitigated risk associated with fracking is induced seizmicity (unintended artificial earthquakes) in areas of high well concentration.
Induced seizmicity may compromise improperly designed/constructed well shaft heads and cause local contamination of drinking water.

Few important notes. Most hydraulic frac targets are kilometres deep, not metres. Frac fluid is 99.95% water, which is always taken from non-potable water sources. Drinking water sources actually do not provide a fast enough rate of charge to supply frac water supply requirements. 0.05% of the frac fluid is proprietary chemicals. Note this does not factor in the proppant, which is usually sand.

Note that all natural water sources also contain similar surprising quantities of toxic chemicals particularly heavy metals. This is normal in nature and when in small quantities, our bodies have the ability to tolerate it. But this is why water treatment is common practice in first world countries.

Furthermore, the average water use of frac wells is between 20,000m3 and 40,000m3 with a statistical mean around 32,000m3.

Most jurisdictions do not allow fracing anywhere near what is referred to as the "base of groundwater" which changes based on where you live. Most rules require that operators frac much much deeper than this safety depth, to prevent any hope of contamination. Consult your local regulator for info on this.

Finally, the movie Gasland which has stirred up most of the anti fracing sentiment, is largely fictitious, as admitted personally by the director of the film, who admitted that he aims to sell tickets as it is "still just a movie". You can find those quotes on Gasland's wikipedia page.

In the interests of fairness it should be pointed out that the statement 2:48 is somewhat inaccurate. It states that the water is subsequently contaminated and is highly toxic. While this is true in certain instances, particularly where regulatory controls are poorly drafted or poorly applied. With conventional fracking surfactants and other additives the statement is somewhat true, although I would hesitate to use the word "highly", there are alternatives that are naturally biodegradable, even some that are fit for human consumption (although I'm pretty sure you wouldn't want to consume them). There are also a number of Oilfield Service Providers that offer mobile purification systems at wellsites, however I won't go into the degree of water cleanliness derived from the process as any statement to this effect would likely be viewed as contentious.The point is that alternatives are available, although they are often more expensive and thus less attractive to many the smaller operators currently working in the US unconventional market. The central problem is arguably a lack of regulatory control to compel operators to employ the more expensive environmentally benign fracking options.

Hydraulic Fracturing occurs many kilometers under the surface, and water wells are far, far shallower than that. There are innumerable layers of impermiable rocks between where the fracking is happening and where the water is retrieved from. If the natural gas couldn't make its way up through the layers, then there is no way possible that the liquid and chemicals (which are more viscous and denser than natural gas) could work its way up. In addition, most of the water pumped down for frack jobs is salt water retrieved from deep within the Earth, often from the same well that it is pumped back into.  In addition, most frack fluid is reused/recycled, to reduce the need for more water. 

As for the methane that is way worse than carbon dioxide reduced, it is usually burned off in gas flares to change it into CO2, and what isn't burned will decay naturally in a short amount of time to CO2. "The compressibility of water is a function of pressure and temperature. At 0 °C, at the limit of zero pressure, the compressibility is 5.1×10−10 Pa−1.
